Graphical abstract The strongly correlated perovskites RNiO3 (R = rare earth) have been featured of appreciable ionic conduction and catalytic activity in solid oxide fuel cells (SOFCs) in recent years. In this study, to tap more potentials of RNiO3, we promote a typical member from this material family, LaNiO3 (LNO) for SOFC electrolyte membrane use in a form of composite with Ce0.8Sm0.2O2-δ (SDC) by taking advantage of their ion-conducting and catalytic capabilities. The developed composite materials are found to be competent electrolyte membranes possessing improved ionic conductivities along with good auxiliary catalytic effect to the cell electrode reaction, realizing good fuel cell power outputs of 268–688 mW cm−2 and high OCV above 1.0 V at 530 °C. Comparative study reveals that the 5LNO-5SDC composite gains the highest ionic conductivity (0.203 S cm−1 at 530 °C) and results in the lowest electrode polarization resistance (0.2973 Ω cm2 at 530 °C). It is believed the catalytic activity of 5LNO-5SDC is mainly inherited from the LNO phase while benefiting from the high mixed ion–electron conduction. To manifest the reliability of the material, further studies in terms of rectification curve and cell durability tests have been carried out, certifying the Schottky junction effect and material stability in the fuel cells. Keywords LaNiO3-Ce0.8Sm0.2O2-δ composite SOFCs Electrolyte membrane Improved ionic conductivity Mixed conduction Catalytic activity 1 Introduction Solid oxide fuel cells (SOFCs) are famous of direct conversion of chemical energy into electrical energy with high efficiency and low environmental footprint and have attracted great attention in energy technology research in the past decades [1–3]. However, high temperatures associated high cost issues largely restrict the SOFC commercialization for portable and distributed system application [4]. These have made worldwide research and technological efforts focus on reducing the operating temperatures to advance the development of SOFCs [5]. Unfortunately, due to the slow reaction kinetics and ionic transport at reduced temperatures, so far great challenges still remain for developing low-temperature (LT < 600 °C) SOFCs. Recently, Zhou et al [6] have reported a strongly correlated perovskite, SmNiO3 (SNO) for electrolyte application though it possess original metallic (high electronic) conductivity. They found that the electronic conduction of SNO was effectively suppressed through a Mott transition induced by spontaneous hydrogen incorporation in fuel cell process, and demonstrated a micro-fabricated SOFC using such SNO as the electrolyte with good performance, 225 mW/cm2 at 500 °C. This work presents a new strategy to develop advanced electrolyte based on this type of material and its property of strong electron correlations. Besides, in this strongly correlated perovskite RNiO3 (R = La, Sm, Gd, Nd), another typical member LNO has been employed as an electrode material for new generation energy devices such as metal-air batteries, fuel cells, capacitors [7–9] etc. The high conductivity and its perovskite crystal structure make it easy to integrate with other oxides [10,11] to construct multifunctional devices. It has attracted enormous interest due to its decent electrochemical activity. The perovskite structure of LNO is stable only below 1230–1270 K at atmospheric oxygen pressure. It will decompose into La2NiO3+δ with a K2NiF4-type structure and NiO after heating continues [12,13]. Lu et al. found the La2NiO4+δ with relatively high oxygen ionic conductivity. After mixed with LNO for preparing composite cathode, the performance of SOFC was enhanced significantly [14]. Chiu developed a series of composites made of La2NiO4+δ and LaNiO3 for cathode uses in intermediate-temperature SOFCs to enhance the electrochemical performance. The results indicated that the weight ratios significantly affected the performances of the cathode. The cathode consisting of 40 wt% LaNiO3 exhibited the lowest polarization resistance at 700 °C in air [15]. In addition, LNO has attracted wide attention both in its bulk state [16,17] and in thin films [18,19] owing to a large effective mass and enhanced Pauli paramagnetism coupled with strong electronic correlations. The metal–insulator (MI) transitions behavior occurs in LNO mainly due to an increasing amount of oxygen vacancies [20,21]. Based on recent advances of SNO for LT-SOFCs application [6], this work further investigates LNO, another member from the strongly correlated perovskite family, to develop high ionic conductivity while sustaining its good catalytic activity through a heterostructure approach to form the composites with Ce0.8Sm0.2O2-δ (SDC), [22–24]. The developed LNO-SDC composites with various weight ratios are evaluated as electrolyte membranes in SOFCs at low temperatures (490–530 °C) to study their ionic and catalytic properties. 2 Materials and methods Preparing of LaNiO3 (LNO). Stoichiometric amount of La(NO3)3·6H2O, Ni(NO3)2, citric acid were dissolved in deionized water with a weight ratio of 1:1:3 to form lanthanum nitrate solution, nickel nitrate solution and citric acid solution respectively. Lanthanum nitrate solution was mixed into the nickel nitrate solution and the mixture were stir for half an hour under 80 °C. Moderate amount of citric acid solution was drop into the mixture slowly. The liquid appears as a light green transparent gel to form a metal ion complex. The sol was stirred at 80 °C for 4 h and most of the water was distilled out. The complex was polymerized into a thick gel. The gel was dried in a dry box under 120 °C for many hours to form dry gel. It was sintering at 700 °C for 4 h to obtain the LNO powder. Preparing of SDC (Ce0.8Sm0.2O2-δ). The co-precipitation method was adopted for the SDC preparation. Stoichiometric amounts of Sm(NO3)3·6H2O and Ce(NO3)3·6H2O were dissolved in deionized water (1 M mixture solution) with a molar ratio of Sm3+:Ce3+=1:4. Then 0.5 M NH4HCO3 solution was added to the above solution in a molar ratio of = 1:3. A white precipitant was finally formed, which then filtered, washed several times, and dried at 120 °C for 24 h. The resulting material was sintered at 800 °C for 4 h and then ground to obtain the SDC powder. Preparing of LNO-SDC. LNO-SDC composites were prepared by blending and grinding the resultant LNO and SDC powders in various ratios of 7:3, 5:5 and 3:7, respectively. The produced composite powders were labeled as 7LNO-3SDC, 5LNO-5SDC, 3LNO-7SDC. Fabricating of electrodes. Commercial LiNi0.8Co0.15Al0.05O2 (NCAL) powder mixed with pine oil alcohol with a certain stoichiometry to get the slurry. It was pasted onto the surface of Ni foam and then dried at 120 °C more than 60 min. The prepared NCAL-pasted Ni foam was applied as anode and cathode and current collectors simultaneously. Fabricating of the single cell. The prepared LNO-SDC composites was employed as electrolyte and the manufactured NCAL-pasted Ni foam was used as anode and cathode simultaneously. In this case, a symmetrical cell composed of LNO-SDC electrolyte is sandwiched between NCAL coated on Ni-foam electrodes under a load of 8–10 MPa into one pellet. In the end, the device with a thickness of approximate 1.7 mm and active area of 0.64 cm2 was obtained. According to the different ratio of the LNO and SDC, the cells are also labeled as 7LNO-3SDC, 5LNO-5SDC, 3LNO-7SDC. After being placed onto the testing fixture and before performance evaluation, the devices were pre-heated at 600 °C for 30 min. The crystal phase structure of the synthesized powder was analyzed by X-ray diffraction (XRD, Germany, Bruker corporation) with Cu Kα (λ = 1.54060 Å) source. The microstructural and morphological studies of the materials were analyzed using a field emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM, Merlin) and high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM). The fuel cell performance and electrochemical properties were measured at 490–530 °C by using an electronic load instrument (IT8511, ITECH Electrical Co., Ltd., China) under H2/air condition. The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was conducted using Gamry Reference 3000. The EIS measurements were carried out under open-circuit potentials (OCP) in a frequency range of 0.1 Hz to 1 MHz. The results extracted from impedance spectra were analyzed using ZSimpWin software. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Crystalline structure and morphology Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of the as-prepared samples. The XRD pattern of SDC is indexed to a cubic fluorite structure. The 2θ values of peaks slightly shift towards higher angle in comparison with that of standard diffraction pattern for pure CeO2 (PDF No. 43–1002), indicating that Sm has been co-doped into ceria lattice. The pattern of the as-prepared LNO is well identified as LaNiO3 (PDF No. 34–1077) with a perovskite structure [14]. The XRD pattern of SDC-LNO composite reveals the co-existence of SDC and LNO, and no other phases can be detected, indicating no obvious interaction between these two materials. The morphologies of the as-synthesized materials were investigated by SEM and HRTEM. The SEM images of SDC and LNO particles are shown in Fig. 2 (a) and (b), respectively. It can be found that the particle size of the SDC ranges from 50 nm to 100 nm and the LNO ranges from 300 nm to 900 nm by the large ones from Fig. 2 (a) and (b), respectively. The LNO particles show faceted and occasionally irregular shape. The composite material of LNO-SDC exhibits a morphology made of nano-sized SDC particles and irregular sheet or block-shaped LNO. The non-uniform shape of the samples may be contributed to the non-strict preparation processes. Nevertheless, it can be seen from Fig. 3 that a homogenous contact between LNO and SDC particles forms interfacial regions between the ionic conductor (SDC) and semiconductor (LNO). This can contribute to promote the ionic conductivity of the composite electrolyte via interfacial conduction [25]. The cross section of the LNO-SDC fuel cell device has also been examined by SEM. As can be seen in Fig. 2 (c), the thickness of the electrolyte layer is 530 μm, and thicknesses for cathode and anode are 620 and 570 μm, respectively. The three layers corresponding to NCAL-Ni electrodes, LNO-SDC electrolyte are clearly distinguished in the left SEM image. An enlarged SEM image for the same cross-section is also depicted in Fig. 2 (d), showing the interface between the dense electrolyte layer and porous anode. Fig. 3 (a) provides a TEM image of 5LNO-5SDC with different amplifications to depict its distribution of nano-scale particles and massive contacts between the grains or particles. Fig. 3(b) further gives a typical HR-TEM image of the 5LNO-5SDC sample. It can be seen the well-defined crystalline fringes with d spacing of 0.273 nm corresponding to the (1 1 0) crystal plane of LNO, and the d spacing of a SDC grain is identified to be around 0.323 nm, which is slightly smaller than that of pure CeO2 (0.357 nm) due to partial substitution of Sm atoms for Ce atoms in CeO2. Three other typical HR-TEM images showing the heterointerface regions are also presented in Fig. S1. The heterointerfaces between LNO and SDC are therefore clearly identified. The evidences observed from the lattice distortion and defect accumulation in the interface area support interfacial functionalities such as ionic transportation [26]. 3.2 Electrochemical performance The fuel cells using the prepared LNO-SDC electrolytes with different weight ratios were tested at temperatures ranging from 490 °C to 530 °C. As shown in Fig. 4 , there is no distinct short-circuiting problem occurring to all these devices. High open circuit voltages (OCVs) in the range of 1.00–1.02 V are obtained at 530 °C. Compared to the pure SDC electrolyte, the power outputs of the LNO-SDC electrolyte fuel cells display significant improvements. With increasing amount of LNO in the LNO-SDC, the maximum power density is raised from 405 mW cm−2 (pure SDC) to 688 mW cm−2 (for 5LNO-5SDC). Thereafter, the power density drops when the weight ratio of LNO reaches 70 wt%. The results indicate that too excess LNO can cause current leakage issue and there is an optimized LNO content for the LNO-SDC composite. According to the experiments, the weight ratio of the semiconductor and ionic conductor phases has an important effect on its electrochemical performance, and it is finally found 50 wt% LNO-50 wt% SDC is the optimum composition. Hence, a proper ratio is one of the key factors to reach optimized power outputs in such mixed electron and ion conduction system [27]. The electrochemical performances of the fuel cells at reduced temperatures are shown in Fig. 4 (b-d). The OCV of the cell based on 5LNO-5SDC maintains above 1.0 V at temperature from 490 °C to 530 °C. The corresponding maximum power density of the device increases significantly from 258 mW cm−2 at 490 °C to 688 mW cm−2 at 530 °C due to the thermally activated ion transportation in LNO-SDC. Within the same temperature range, the maximum power densities of 3LNO-7SDC and 7LNO-3SDC cells increase from 212 mW cm−2 to 434 mW cm−2 and from 102 mW cm−2 to 253 mW cm−2, respectively, revealing appreciable but lower results than those of 5LNO-5SDC cell at each testing point (490, 510 and 530 °C). This difference should be a result of the diverse properties of the composites that caused by various LNO/SDC weight ratios, hence, conducting and catalytic properties of the composite materials are further studied in the following parts. 3.3 Electrical conductivity and catalytic activity Taking into account the high power densities and OCVs acquired by these LNO-SDC fuel cells, two possibilities might be occurred to the LNO-SDC composite electrolyte: i) LNO-SDC is same as a conventional electrolyte possessing ionic conduction and negligible electronic conduction, such as, SDC; ii) LNO-SDC as a semiconducting-ionic conductor with mixed electron and ion conduction, but the electrons is blocked to pass through the device by some special mechanisms. To reveal the underlying processes and clarify which possibility is, we further determine the electrical conductivities of the LNO-SDC with different weight ratios. Fig. 5 (a) displays Nyquist curves of the cells of 3LNO-7SDC, 5LNO-5SDC and 7LNO-3SDC acquired in H2/air at 530 °C, respectively. The EIS of the 5LNO-5SDC at the temperatures of 490–530 °C is shown in Fig. 5 (b). These plot can be modeled by an equivalent circuit (inset) mode of R1/Rp1(CEP1)/ Rp2(CEP2), where R represents a resistance, and CEP is the constant phase element representing a non-ideal capacitor. With reducing frequency, EIS arcs correspond to the ohmic and electrodes processes. In each curve, the intersection at the real axis at high frequency region relates to the ohmic resistance (R1). The small semicircle or arc at intermediate frequencies presents the charge transfer. The third process with a larger arc at low frequencies should be contributed to the mass transfer behaviors of electrode [28]. The last one is highly linked to the electrode performance, especially oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) kinetic process in the cathode. Through simulation, the fitting parameters extracted from ZSimpWin are summarized in Table 1 (data for 530 °C). The corresponding characteristic capacitance (Ci) for each process can be calculated by the following formula: C i = ( R i C P E ) 1 / n R i According to the EIS analysis, the total electrical conductivity ( σ t ) of LNO-SDC composite electrolyte which is contributed by both ionic and electronic resistances can be acquired based on the ohmic resistance values [29]. On the other hand, the ionic conductivity ( σ i ) of LNO-SDC can be attained from the I-V characteristics, since the linear part in the central linear region reflects ohmic polarization of the I-V curve, which is mainly contributed by the ionic resistance from the electrolyte layer [30]. This method is feasible in our case because in the intermediate part (higher current region) of the curve, the kinetically affected parameter polarization resistance (Rp) will be significantly reduced with the increasing of current density and become far smaller compared to ohmic resistance, in this way the ohmic polarization which is proportional to current density will dominate the total polarizations in a form of linear I-V characteristic. By this mean, the electrolyte ionic resistance can be estimated and the corresponding σ i is calculated as listed in Table 2 . Consequently, the electronic conductivity ( σ e ) can be obtained from the total conductivity according to: (2) σ e = σ t - σ i It is found the three LNO-SDC samples have gained high ionic conductivities at 530 °C, and the 5LNO-5SDC sample exhibits the highest ionic conductivity of 0.203 S cm−1, which should be one factor leading to the best fuel cell performance. Meanwhile, the three samples also sustain a high level of electronic conductivities at 530 °C Inherited from LNO. The results reveal that the developed LNO-SDC has mixed electron and ion conduction. The extraordinarily high ionic conductivity obtained by the 5LNO-5SDC is much ahead of those of well-known O2– conducting electrolytes YSZ and GDC at the same temperature [31], also superior to the ionic conductivity of H-SNO (2.26 × 10−3 S cm−1) [6]. Worth noting is that our I-V curves which show almost all linear behavior still contain a few Rp, so the estimated conductivity results reveal the minimum ionic conductivity, which is slightly lower than the actual values. This estimation is mainly for attaining the ionic conduction and thus the electronic conductivity can be extracted from the total one to investigate whether the LNO-SDC composites are mixed ion–electron conductive or not. Furthermore, the catalytic functionality of the 5LNO-5SDC composites is studied based on the EIS result. Since NCAL is used as the electrodes in our fuel cell devices, the so-called “catalytic functionality” is actually an auxiliary catalytic effect of the 5LNO-5SDC that contribute to the electrode/electrolyte interface to facilitate the electrode reaction, in addition to the major catalytic function offered up by NCAL. According to the attained C1 and C2 from EIS analysis, which are from 0.0181F to 0.8353F, it is known the surface oxygen diffusion, absorption and dissociation processes are dominant in the fuel cell [32]. Thus, the Rp1CEP1 is corresponding to intermediate frequency-arc that attributed to the charge transfer while the Rp2CEP2 is for low frequency-arc representing the mass transfer processes of the electrode. The sum of Rp1 and Rp2 reflects the total Rp, which is 0.2973 Ω cm2 for 5LNO-5SDC cell, 0.3612 and 0.4695 Ω cm2 for 3LNO-7SDC and 7LNO-3SDC cells, respectively. The lower electrode polarization resistance suggests that the 5LNO-5SDC has more effective electro-catalysts with fast electrode kinetics compared to other two samples, which is another factor leading to the best fuel cell performance. It is believed that the good catalytic activity of 5LNO-5SDC is inherited from LNO and simultaneously benefiting from the high mixed ion–electron conduction. Such feature of LNO-SDC will help to improve the electrode reaction, especially ORR, at electrolyte/electrode interface when it used as the electrolyte membrane of a fuel cell. To show the catalytic activity of LNO in our fuel cell, the EIS of a Ni-NCAL/SDC/NCAL-Ni cell in H2/air was also measured as presented in Fig. 6 for more intuitive comparison with that of NCAL-Ni/5LNO-5SDC/NCAL-Ni cell in Fig. 5(b). It is found the Rp of 5LNO-5SDC cell are distinctly smaller than that of SDC cell, reflecting its faster electrode reaction. Comparatively, the only difference between the two devices is that LNO has been introduced into the electrolyte of 5LNO-5SDC cell, presenting at the electrolyte/electrode interfaces and contribute its catalytic function, while in the SDC cell only SDC presents at electrolyte/electrode interfaces. In this way, although the NCAL electrodes play the major role on electrocatalytic activity, the LNO-SDC layer can additionally provide an auxiliary catalytic effect to extend the triple phase boundary (TPB) area and facilitate the electrode reaction. The small Rp values of 5LNO-5SDC cell are also found to be much lower than those of a previously reported NCAL-Ni/GDC/NCAL-Ni cell with the same electrodes and configuration but single ionic conductor electrolyte (without LNO), indicative of the good catalytic activity of 5LNO-5SDC [33]. To further show the catalytic activity of LNO, we also used Ag electrode instead of NCAL to construct a Ag/5LNO-5SDC/Ag symmetrical cell for EIS test at 490, 510, 530 and 600 °C, the results are presented in Fig. 7 . The total Rp consists of two rate-determining processes which are reflected in the two semi-arcs of the EIS curves exhibit small values, in particular, exhibiting much lower value than that in an Ag/SDC/Ag cell [34]. As reported, the Ag/SDC/Ag cell has an Rp of 16 Ω cm2 at 600 °C, whereas in our case the Rp of Ag/LNO-SDC/Ag is small as 3.45 Ω cm2. The much lower polarization resistance should be due to the introduction of LNO into SDC, which bring about good catalytic effect in the composite. Therefore, the LNO-SDC is also a catalytic membrane which can realize both ionic transport and electrocatalyst functions as our latest work on a triple-conducting perovskite that shows both electrolyte and electrode functionalities for low-temperature SOFCs [35]. On basis of above micro-structure, conductivity and EIS results, it is recognized that the catalysis effect of LNO-SDC interface is mainly reflected in the high mixed ion–electron conduction. This effect should be a result of the interfacial conduction at LNO/SDC heterointerface. According to previous reports, great enhancement of ionic conduction have been detected in heterostructures formed by SDC and perovskite SrTiO3 (STO) [36] GDC and STO [37] and YSZ and STO [38]. This ionic conduction enhancement behavior has been interpreted in terms of atomic reconstruction at the interface between highly dissimilar fluorite and perovskite structures, which provides both a high-mobility disordered oxygen plane and a large number of carriers [38,39]. The mechanism can be also used to explain the high interfacial ionic conductivity of our 5LNO-5SDC, in which, heterointerface between fluorite SDC and perovskite LNO that has been characterized by HR-TEM image (Fig. 3) is able to create disordered oxygen channels and massive carriers for fast oxygen ions to transport. Besides, the high electronic conductivity of LNO has also been sustained in the 5LNO-5SDC composite through the LNO/SDC heterointerfaces, because the ion-conducting SDC phase is not completely electron-insulating and thus can allow electrons from LNO to pass through. In the way, the 5LNO-5SDC composite can gain a high mixed ion–electron conduction to facilitate the charge transfer at electrolyte/electrode region, realizing an extend TPB area and promoted HOR/ORR activities of the cell. 3.4 Schottky junction effect and fuel cell stability Above findings prove the authenticity of the aforementioned second assumption that the developed LNO-SDC possesses mixed electron and ion conduction. Conventionally speaking, high electronic conductivity of LNO-SDC electrolyte membrane is unfavorable for the operation of SOFCs, since short-circuiting issue can cause OCV losses and performance degradation when electrons transport through the LNO-SDC layer. However, though high mixed electronic and ionic conductivities have been confirmed in the LNO-SDC membranes, there is no electronic short circuit problem. Thus, there should be some mechanisms preventing the electrons from passing through the internal device. To confirm whether the LNO can turn into an insulating phase in H2 atmosphere similar to the Mott-transition effect of SNO, an Pt/LNO/Pt fuel cell based on individual LNO electrolyte was fabricated and operated, exhibiting a low OCV of 0.24 V and peak power density of 43 mW cm−2 at 530 °C, as shown in Fig. S2. This indicates the LNO by itself has weaker Mott-transition effect than SNO in H2, which has also been experimentally observed and reported by Chen et al. [40]. Therefore, there should be some other effects which act more effectively in suppressing leakage current rather than the Mott-transition of LNO. On basis of this, considering the semiconductor nature of LNO and the used anode NCAL, we attribute the electronic blocking mechanism mainly to a Schottky junction effect formed between the anodic metallic Ni and semiconductor LNO. As reported previously, the anodic NCAL can be easily reduced to metallic Ni in hydrogen and forms a metal–semiconductor contact (M−S contact) with the semiconductor layer, which may establish space charge region and set up a barrier to prevent electrons from passing through [41–43]. In this process, the electrons close to the metal will leave the semiconductor until the condition of thermal equilibrium is fulfilled, and this may lead to a barrier height at M − S interface for blocking electron transition from metal to semiconductor [44]. This type of contact forms Schottky junction, which can be characterized by I-V characteristic of the junction under bias voltage. In order to verify the Schottky junction in our LNO-SDC fuel cell, the response currents as a function of bias voltage for a NCAL-Ni/LNO-SDC half cell was tested at 530 °C with H2 flow to the NCAL anode. Bias voltage was applied to the two side of half cell, and the current response was recorded. The half cell in H2 condition simulates the operational status of the fuel cell at anode/electrolyte interface during operation. As a result, the recorded current (as shown in Fig. 8 ) presents an apparent rectification response emerged in the I-V characteristic, indicative of a Schottky barrier formed between reduced anode and membrane layer. This rectification should be ascribed to the in-situ formed Schottky junction between anodic Ni and semiconductor LNO. The barrier height of Schottky junction would prevent the electron flow from anode to LNO-SDC layer. In this way, the high OCVs and excellent power outputs of our fuel cells can be guaranteed in spite of high electronic conductivity in LNO-SDC. Furthermore, the stability the 5LNO-5SDC fuel cell was assessed to confirm whether the developed 5LNO-5SDC composite capably support a stable operation of our fuel cell. As shown in Fig. 9 , the cell can be subjected to a 62 h-stable operation under stationary current density of 150 mA cm−2 at 530 °C in H2/air, showing a slight decrease of working voltage at initial stage (0 ~ 10 h) from 0.67 V to 0.62 V, and then following by a constant working voltage of 0.62 V retained for the duration of more than 50 h. The slight decrease should be a result of the initial slightly instable step of LNO and SDC because of reduction in H2, and the rest 52 h-stability is very likely attributed to a fact that only few LNO particles on the surface of the 5LNO-5SDC pellet were really reduced while most surface region and the internal particles kept intact reflecting by the constant voltage. This means that the 5LNO-5SDC generally remains constant in H2/air atmosphere and is able to support a stable fuel cell operation at low temperature. For longer-term durability (greater than500 h), more compatible electrode materials are desired to match LNO-SDC, and the density of the LNO-SDC layer should also be improved and optimized, which will be a subject of our follow-up work. To sum up these features, a schematic diagram is proposed in Fig. 10 to show the working mechanism of LNO-SDC in fuel cell. The electrolyte layer possesses mixed high ionic conductivity and contributes additional electrocatalyst function, capable of transporting fast oxygen ions from cathode to anode and synchronously promoting the fuel cell electrocatalyst reactions, HOR and ORR. To show the non-short-circuit behaviour of the cell, Schottky junction effect is also illustrated in the figure at anode/electrode interface to describe the electron blocking process. These findings and analysis prove that by compositing typical electrolyte SDC with perovskite LNO, both good catalytic and electrolyte functionality can be realized in one material, pointing out a new approach to promote fuel cell electrode activity and improve the ionic conduction of electrolyte. More importantly, the used LNO is from the famous strongly correlated perovskite oxides family, which has attracted unprecedented attention in recent years for fuel cell, lithium ion shuttles, electric-field sensors, super-broadband-tunable photonics researches, etc. [6,45–49]. In this study, via a totally different approach in terms of compositing, LNO was investigated for the first time from both ion-conducting and catalytic perspectives to show its feasibility for developing not only electrolyte membrane but also good catalyst in fuel cells, demonstrating once again the great promise of strongly correlated perovskite for fuel cell application and pointing out another effective method to shape such type of material in fuel cell electrolyte. The proposed approach and materials are deserved to be generalized in LT-SOFCs or other electrochemistry devices, based on strongly correlated perovsikte RNiO3 (R = rare earth) with significant importance for both fundamental and applied research. 4 Conclusions In summary, a new composite made of strongly correlated perovskite LNO and a typical ionic conductor SDC has been developed and successfully demonstrated as electrolyte membrane in SOFCs. Attractive fuel cell performances of 268–688 mW cm−2 with high OCVs of over 1.0 V have been obtained at 530 °C. Through electrical and electrochemical studies, the prepared LNO-SDC composites were found to have mixed ion–electron conduction and good catalytic function and auxiliary catalytic effect to the electrode reaction. Comparison study among the three composites reveals that the 5LNO-5SDC obtained the highest ionic conductivity of 0.203 S cm−1 at 530 °C and the lowest electrode polarization resistance of 0.2973 Ω cm2 at 530 °C of the cell, thus presenting the best fuel cell performance. The catalytic activity of 5LNO-5SDC should be mainly inherited from the LNO phase while benefiting from the high mixed ion–electron conduction. Furthermore, the Schottky junction effect was confirmed in the 5LNO-5SDC fuel cell to interpret the non-short circuit phenomenon, and durability test of over 60 h was undertaken to show the reliability of the device. These findings suggest that the LNO-SDC heterostructure composites are highly promising electrolyte membrane materials with multi-functions for new advanced SOFCs. coredata.dc:description: The strongly correlated perovskites RNiO3 (R = rare earth) have been featured of appreciable ionic conduction and catalytic activity in solid oxide fuel cells (SOFCs) in recent years. In this study, to tap more potentials of RNiO3, we promote a typical member from this material family, LaNiO3 (LNO) for SOFC electrolyte membrane use in a form of composite with Ce0.8Sm0.2O2-δ (SDC) by taking advantage of their ion-conducting and catalytic capabilities. The developed composite materials are found to be competent electrolyte membranes possessing improved ionic conductivities along with good auxiliary catalytic effect to the cell electrode reaction, realizing good fuel cell power outputs of 268–688 mW cm−2 and high OCV above 1.0 V at 530 °C. Comparative study reveals that the 5LNO-5SDC composite gains the highest ionic conductivity (0.203 S cm−1 at 530 °C) and results in the lowest electrode polarization resistance (0.2973 Ω cm2 at 530 °C). It is believed the catalytic activity of 5LNO-5SDC is mainly inherited from the LNO phase while benefiting from the high mixed ion–electron conduction. To manifest the reliability of the material, further studies in terms of rectification curve and cell durability tests have been carried out, certifying the Schottky junction effect and material stability in the fuel cells.
coredata.dc:title: Catalytic membrane with high ion–electron conduction made of strongly correlated perovskite LaNiO3 and Ce0.8Sm0.2O2-δ for fuel cells
